['Shitty developers is really the only reason . You could argue that if I put in a password of " 12345 " ... did I mean it or was the space accidental ? If it \'s accidental and I do n\'t realise I did it , next time I login I wo n\'t be able to , because I \'ll be putting in " 12345 " which wo n\'t match . The workaround here is to force users to confirm their passwords . So type it in once , type it in again , if there is a space in both then the user meant to put it there . However , it annoys me . Many sites allow it , many sites do n\'t . Office 365 is a good example of a huge website that does n\'t .', 'Whenever you get an error message about an invalid character in your password , it \'s a huge red flag that the people who built that website have no idea what they \'re doing . It \'s also likely that they \'re storing your password in plain text , which is really bad , security - wise . If you want to confirm that a website was coded by utter morons , hit the " I forgot my password " button and see what happens - ideally , you \'ll get a link you can click to reset your password . On some sites , however , they will actually * email you your password * , which is a dead giveaway that they store it in plain text and know nothing at all about secure coding . Do n\'t give personal information to such sites , and DO NOT give them your credit card information above all .', 'A lot of database servers trim starting and ending whitespace in a variety of datatypes and circumstances and it can be used maliciously in usernames . Consider your username : MrsIvestermcbean it \'s impossible to discern from these different usernames by most people : MrsIvestermcbean MrsIvestermcbean even without them , I could probably get 2 or 3 of your friends tricked with the username : MrsIvesterrncbean For passwords , there \'s also a ton of places you can run into trouble by allowing spaces , even if you \'re hashing . A lot of frameworks , and browsers would have problems with a password like ` " " ` , a lot of database operations may trim " c " to " c " or " c " . You end up with a support nightmare , database migration complications , more difficulty fighting injection , and other headaches . You end up with AIM style solutions where you can have spaces in your name , but they ca n\'t be meaningful . Also , keep in mind HTML does n\'t display multiple spaces in a row , so you \'d end up needing post retrieval re - parsing functions to make sure two names that differed only by number of consecutive spaces displayed without looking * exactly * the same .']

['Public perception is * always * important . It makes selling to businesses / governments easier - if the population or demographics for a business / government are more familiar or are happier with Boeing over Airbus , its more likely that entity will go with Boeing . Companies and governments do care about that sort of thing , so by taking the time to drum up public support , you make it more likely that a particular entity will say , " yes , your company is well regarded by our customers / people / lemurs , so we are more comfortable with negotiations "', "It creates a kind of association where brand = product . If you want an mp3 player you think oh ill get an ipod , you wo n't even bother to think of the other brands . Other examples : Velcro , Kleenex , Q - tips , Oreos .", 'In addition , it helps with recruiting . Making yourself a well - known name will make people more likely to apply to your company , allowing you to pick and choose employees .']

['It \'s not really a population boom per se but a gradual increase . Population booms are mostly a thing of the past ( outside sub - Saharan Africa ) . Two factors are immigrants and birth rates . The US takes on a lot of immigrants , more than any country on earth , both legal and illegal . They take on a million legal immigrants and an unknown amount of illegal immigrants a year . Canada , it should be noted takes the highest * percentage * of immigrants . The US has citizenship by birth , so immigrants that come here and have children automatically gain citizenship for them and tend to stay . Generally the rule of thumb is , immigrants come from poorer countries and the birthrate is higher so the women tend to have more children than regular American women . This only lasts one generation as immigrants assimilate very quickly in America , but this is the reason for the increasing population . China is not experiencing a population boom , in fact , China \'s population is leveling off . You can call it good or bad , but China \'s birth policies are working . China \'s birthrate is very low now and by the next decade , India will pass China as the most populated country on earth . A sad side effect is that many little girls that were to be born were aborted , abandoned , given away or killed after birth because of the cultural preference for a " male heir " for a family . This has really messed up the gender ratio in China and there are an estimated 50 million Chinese men who will NEVER marry . That \'s more men than in all of Germany who will be single for life unless they manage to find brides overseas . At current birth rates , China \'s population will start to shrink and some estimates have China with 300 million fewer citizens at the end of the century . [ As for other countries , the birth rate rate worldwide \\(outside of sub - Saharan Africa\\ ) is falling dramatically . ] ( URL_0 ) The world \'s population is actually leveling off and is normal . I can almost promise you that in 20 years from now the map I linked will mostly be light blue . Countries need basic and cheap unskilled manual labor and they use immigration to offset the need for this . It depends how much immigration they want to receive and that is the main reason for population increases , not births so much anymore .', 'Actually , much of the Western world experienced a [ baby boom ] ( URL_0 ) following World War II , including most of Western Europe .', "Let 's not forget that the UK , France and Germany all had population booms in the 19th century as a result of increased food production , which provided the labor capital required for their industrial revolutions . The US and China were just late to the party ."]

["Basically too much salt can increase your blood pressure ( bad ) as your body has limited ability to remove it . The reason salt increases your blood pressure is due to a concept called homeostasis . Say you have two water tanks with a pipe in between them with the level equal .. if you add water to one , half that water will go into the other and the levels would be equal again .. this is homeostasis . Homeostasis also applies to the concentration of liquids . If you added salt to one of these tanks ( A LOT ) , water would go to the tank you added salt to , to correct the concentration .. in this case the salt concentration pressure ( oncotic ) must over come the pressure of the fluids ( hydrostatic pressure ) to see a change . So if you add salt into your body , you increase the concentration of electrolytes , therefore more water is retained to correct that concentration .. and increased volume = increased pressure .. think about a balloon , as you fill it up with more and more air the pressure increases till it explodes ! = increased blood pressure . Tried to keep it LI5 as possible .. first time not sure if that 's a good job :P", "I want to take a different approach . Drinking salt water kills people . That is the fact . Why ? Because NaCl ( that is what salt is ) when its in water it forms two ions ( Na+ and Cl- ) . These two molecules attract water around them as they have a charge . So when you drink the salt water , these ions in your body attract water , they are more stable ( happier ) with lots of water surrounding them . Because Na+ and Cl- ca n't get into your cells as easily as water can , they end up actually SUCKING water out of your cells . That is why salt water can dehydrate you . the actual term for this area of science is Osmolarity if you want to look into it more , but it does n't really get any more exciting than this ... !", 'too much of anything is bad for you :) on a more serious ( and uninformed ) note , I know that salt increases water retention which has a direct effect on blood pressure ( it increases it and with it the risks of heart attacks , strokes etc ) . > Salt makes your body hold on to water . If you eat too much salt , the extra water stored in your body raises your blood pressure . So , the more salt you eat , the higher your blood pressure .']

['Interestingly , this phrase is commonly translated in a slightly wrong way . The correct translation of Platos phrase " oÃ®da ouk eidÅs " should be " I know , that i do n\'t know " which is quite a difference . What it means can be understood in Socrates \' concept of \' aporia \' which includes the notion that nothing can be known for sure . This permanent uncertainty regarding ones views and opinions was one of Socrates \' most important concerns .', "It 's basically a statement against being ignorant . To quote : > I am wiser than this man , for neither of us appears to know anything great and good ; but he fancies he knows something , although he knows nothing ; whereas I , as I do not know anything , so I do not fancy I do . In this trifling particular , then , I appear to be wiser than he , because I do not fancy I know what I do not know . Or a dumbed down version : > I am wiser , because he thinks he knows things he does not know ; while I do n't think I know things that I do know .", "I learned a great explanation of this about 1 - 2 years ago . I ca n't remember it as clearly as I wish , so my answer might not be entirely accurate . Socrates was attempting to prove that he knew something .. anything . However , it seemed that trying to support any claim with evidence required further explanation of a simpler component ( that is , you ca n't understand fire if you do n't understand how fuel , heat , and combustion interact ) . This pattern continued until he realized that there was quite literally nothing to prove without some sort of prior knowledge . He was essentially looking for some claim that could be proven with [ innate ] ( URL_0 ) knowledge . Thus , if you can not prove anything because you lack the knowledge of everything , you have proven one thing ; you know nothing . Again , feel free to critique my answer . I really ca n't check my accuracy without a fair bit of research that I do n't wish to do at this moment ."]

["Back when dinosaurs roamed the earth and instead of writing programs for 64b or 32b you wrote programs for a particular instruction set architecture , the Intel 8086 processor used a particularly popular one . A lot of successors to the 8086 had names which also ended in 86 , hence the family were called ` x86 ` . The 8086 was actually a 16b processor , but the x86 term became popular after the 32b 80386 's introduction to the market . x64 is actually a shortened version of x86 - 64 , which is a 64b extension to the x86 instruction set . These days , x86 implies 32b only , whilst x64 means 64b .", "The x86 name refers to the original Intel 8086 processor ( which was only 16 - bit ) . It has been added to and extended over the years , and these days it tends to be used simply as a reference to 32 - bit processors and software . x64 is actually just another extension of x86 , but again it 's used as a simple reference to 64 - bit processors and software .", 'Just want to point out that 64 bit is n\'t formally called " x64 " but x86 - 64 , meaning it is an extension of the x86 family . Its just more simple to call it x64 because people are lazy . URL_0 Edit : mathen described this long before I did , and I fail at catching it .']

['As with almost all foreign policy pronouncements , you should consider what audience is being targeted and what the speaker \'s incentives are . In this case , there are good strategic incentives for Israel / Netanyahu to appear hardline on this deal . First , Netanyahu \'s domestic political situation is dependent on him being seen as hardline on Iran . He has staked his reputation on this position and so , * whatever deal was agreed to * , he has to appear more hardline than that . So , even if he actually thinks that this is a good deal , or a step along the way to a good deal ( good in terms of what Iran would eventually accept ) , he has to publicly appear " pissed off " , using OP \'s language . Second , there is the international audience . The P5 + 1 negotiators ( from the United States , Britain , China , Russia , France and Germany ) will be able to get a better deal from Iran if they can point to a hardline Israel stance and say to Iran , " Look , look at the pressure we are under here . If you do n\'t want Israel to reject the deal ( and maybe unilaterally bomb your nuclear facilities ) , you are going to have to give a better deal " . The P5 + 1 negotiators also seem more reasonable and moderate next to a hardline Israel . In addition to strategic incentives , there is a thing called " fundamental attribution error " . Briefly , this is a psychological phenomenon that all humans are subject to to some extent , where you think that you are a good person and forced to do bad things by your environment , but other people do bad things because they are bad people . So , even though Israelis trust themselves to only use their nuclear weapons defensively , they think that Iran would use nuclear weapons offensively , even if that means effectively committing suicide ( through nuclear retaliation ) . This means that they are far more concerned about * ensuring * Iran does n\'t have nuclear weapon capabilities than is reasonable / rational . These are the most basic and plausible explanations for why Israel is pissed off with the Iran Nuke deal . There are other possibilities but they are more complicated .', "I might be mistaken as I have n't fully read up on this yetbut i m under the impression that Iran will be permitted to enrich its own uranium for use in nuclear reactors . Israel claims that 's a lie and they intend on weaponizing it .", "Israel did n't want a deal as much as they wanted total capitulation from Iran . So not only did Israel not get what they wanted , but they were also very vocal about what they wanted , and the US ignored them and made a deal anyways . Israel not getting what they wanted from the US in regards to an issue like Iran is very unusual , and so they 're likely just as upset about that as they are the actual terms of the deal . On a more personal level , the Israel Prime Minister ( Netanyahu ) has generally campaigned on the idea that Iran is an imminent existential threat that can never be reasoned with , and that his leadership is the only hope that Israel has of surviving . Any deal that potentially reduces the threat from Iran could hurt him politically . edit : spelling"]

["Yes, if you can split your income up over multiple years it will be to your advantage over earning it all in one year.  The reasons are as you mentioned, you get to apply multiple deductions/credits/exemptions to the same income. Rather than just 1 standard deduction, you get to deduct 2 standard deductions, you can double the max saved in an IRA, you benefit more from any non-refundable credits etc. This is partly due to the fact that when you are filing your taxes in Year 1, you can't include anything from Year 2 since it hasn't happened yet. It doesn't make sense for the Government to take into account actions that may or may not happen when calculating your tax bill. There are factors where other year profit/loss can affect your tax liability, however as far as I know these are limited to businesses. Look into Loss Carry Forwarded/Back if you want to know more. Regarding the '30% simple rate', I think you are confusing something that is simple to say with something that is simple to implement.  Are we going to go change the rules on people who expected their mortgage deduction to continue? There are few ways I can think of that are more sure to cause home prices to plummet than to eliminate the Mortgage Interest Deduction. What about removing Student Loan Interest? Under a 30% 'simple' rate, what tools would the government use to encourage trade in specific areas? Will state income tax deduction also be removed? This is going to punish those in a state with a high income tax more than those in states without income tax. Those are all just 'common' deductions that affect a lot of people, you could easily say 'no' to all of them and just piss off a bunch of people, but what about selling stock though? I paid $100 for the stock and I sold it for $120, do I need to pay $36 tax on that because it is a 'simple' 30% tax rate or are we allowing the cost of goods sold deduction (it's called something else I believe when talking about stocks but it's the same idea?) What about if I travel for work to tutor individuals, can I deduct my mileage expenses? Do I need to pay 30% income tax on my earnings and principal from a Roth IRA? A lot of people have contributed to a Roth with the understanding that withdrawals will be tax free, changing those rules are punishing people for using vehicles intentionally created by the government. Are we going to go around and dismantle all non-profits that subsist entirely on tax-deductible donations? Do I need to pay taxes on the employer's cost of my health insurance? What about 401k's and IRA's? Being true to a 'simple' 30% tax will eliminate all 'benefits' from every job as you would need to pay taxes on the value of the benefits. I should mention that this isn't exactly too crazy, there was a relatively recent IRS publication about businesses needing to withhold taxes from their employees for the cost of company supplied food but I don't know if it was ultimately accepted. At the end of the day, the concept of simplifying the tax law isn't without merit, but realize that the complexities of tax law are there due to the complexities of life. The vast majority of tax laws were written for a reason other than to benefit special interests, and for that reason they cannot easily be ignored."]

['It purpose is not to benefit colleges . It is to benefit groups of people who historically have been mistreated , and therefore might have fewer opportunities today .', "Because Affirmative Action is not a recommendation , it is a law . Organizations like schools and businesses who are over a certain capacity must comply with affirmative action laws . Basically , an organization must have a student and/or employee population that reflects the diversity of it 's locale . In lamens terms , if the district Stanford is in has 75 % white people and 25 % black people , their admitance must reflect a simlar statistic . Each region , district , state , city , county , and so on has a difference mandation for affirmative action as far as population percentages are concerned . In the Stanford example I made , their desired admitance due to applicant qualifications may be 85 % white and 15 % black , but they must adjust this to comply with the law . Many will argue against affirmative action because it is a fact that it does rule out better qualified people for positions in order to meet regulaions . But , it is one of many laws put in place to prevent discrimination .", "I would imagine that they 've estimated that having a diverse student body is an important part of being a 21st century collegiate experience ."]

["Well one keeps you alive , and the other is solely for decoration . It 's not hard to see a distinction where one would be morally acceptable to most people and the other would not . There 's even the argument that a * purely * plant - based diet is not quite as healthy as one with * some * meat in it , so you could even claim that eating meat is * necessary * for optimum health .", "because people do n't think about where meat or leather come from , but fur looks like its source .", 'It \'s easier for people from developed nations to say " eating meat is not necessary for survival these days " ; In many parts of the world you do n\'t have the option to be picky about what is on your plate . That being said , there is no such thing as a " kind method " when it comes to raising and then killing animals for their fur . The methods used are barbaric and awful , and often times the animals are subjected to being skinned alive . Their deaths are never quick . It \'s the pain involved in procuring what is a * luxury * item that creates a stigma around fur wearers ( deservedly so ) . However , please remember this is also a regional thing . In other parts of the world , people wear furs as a means to stay warm , and to literally survive harsh , frigid winters . For the record , I \'m a vegan , if that makes any difference . But I learned a long time ago that it \'s useless to try and subject your views on others , especially when often times there are factors involved that all too often are not taken into consideration .']

["Firstly , you need to understand that music , like all sound , is in essence , a wave . You most certainly have seen graphic illustrations of sound , well , music is no different . Now then , there are 2 types of radio waves , AM or Amplitude Modulation and FM or Frequency Modulation . Lets start with the simpler AM . A normal non modulated carrier wave ( which is the wave we will modulate the signal onto , ( just bear with me here ) ) is a simple sine wave . It goes up from zero to a maximum called the amplitude , back down to zero and down to the negative of the amplitude . Now you can see this signal changes in the time domain , but at any instance , it really only has 2 properties : amplitude and frequency ( technically you can add phase too , but we wo nt need that here ) . Now you can chance the amplitude over time , which is called modulating , and with a special circuit that is present in you radio , you can sense the amplitude of a signal at any time ( even when not in the maximum points of the carrier wave ) . Once you know you can do this , it 's easy to understand that if you multiply your original wave ( the music ) with this carrier wave , you get a complex signal , but it 's in essence the carrier wave where the amplitude differs according to the music . One reason why they do this and not simply transmit the music is because now you can have different radio stations on different frequencies . Now , as a I mentioned in the beginning , you also have the more popular FM . Here , instead of changing the amplitude of the carrier wave , you will change its other property , the frequency . The technical and mathimatical details get a little more complex here but you can view it as exactly the same principle and just know there are ways to extract the information from that wave again . If you want more details , just ask .", "There are several ways to get light ( or other electromagnetic waves , like radio ) to carry information . One simple way is to use signalling . You can pulse the light on and off like [ Morse code ] ( URL_2 ) . As long as the sender and receiver both understand the code , you can transmit information . This is actually done in some fiber optic systems . ( They do n't use Morse code , and it is much much faster than a human could do . But it 's the same general idea . ) Another way is to * modulate * the signal . If you think of EM radiation as an [ oscillating set of electric and magnetic fields ] ( URL_0 ) that change their amplitude at some very regular frequency , then you have a lot of ways to change it . If you change the amplitude as a function of the information you want to send , you 've got [ Amplitude Modulation ] ( URL_1 ) . If you change the frequency to be a bit faster / slower according to what you want to send , you 've got [ Frequency Modulation ] ( URL_1 ) . There are also other methods like Phase Modulation that are a bit more complicated . You can think of AM as making the light brighter or dimmer , very rapidly , according to the information you want to send . Think of FM as changing the color of the light very slightly , very rapidly , according to the information you want to send . Of course , you ca n't see radio waves because the human eye does n't detect them , but the concept is exactly the same . Radio is just colors of light we are n't built to detect directly with our senses .", "Radio waves are packets of energy ( in the form of light ) that are oscillating up and down as they travel . This energy can interact with metal , namely the electrons in the antenna to your radio . The electrons adopt the same rate of oscillation as the radio wave ; just like if you push a swing , the swing oscillates at the rate of your arms ( your arms are the radio waves and the swing are electrons in the antenna ) . Since those electrons are moving with certain frequencies and amplitudes ( how frequently they oscillate and how hard ) , they push other electrons along the antenna all the way down into the radio . The oscillation is detected and amplified ( you pushing one swing gets turned into a million swings ) . The amplified oscillation is used to drive the speaker 's cone on the radio . The cone vibrates / oscillates at the exact same frequencies and amplitudes detected from the radio wave . The cone pushes air that then oscillates the same way . The air bumps in to your ear drum and oscillates the same way . Your brain understands this as sound ."]

['A slash is a pretty easy one to tackle . Computers read / as part of a web address and \\ as part of a local address . For instance : C:\\users\\peter_plays_guitar\\ Will get me to my personal files on my computer . But now let \'s pretend I save a file with the name horse\\porn.jpg . C:\\users\\peter_plays_guitar\\horse\\porn.jpg So now my computer is looking not for a horse porn file , but rather a folder named " horse " and a file named " porn.jpg " inside that file . Other characters ( $ , % , :) have their own meanings when locating addresses in your computer \'s hard drive .', "Basically those other characters have special meaning ( in a programming sense ) and would confuse the operating system . There is a more detailed explanation but I 'm on my phone", "Fun fact : you ca n't create a folder named ` con ` either ."]

["If you let ice cream melt and refreeze you 'll find that it gets very hard . Ice cream is soft because it 's frozen foam . Ice cream is churned as it is frozen , and the churning whips the liquid into a foam that has a soft texture when frozen .", 'Two different materials ice cream is not frozen water there are fats in it that form different stractures when frozen .', '1 ) There are sugars and fats in the ice cream that make it require a lower temperature to freeze solid . 2 ) The ice cream is churned while it is freezing locking air into it making it lighter and softer .']

['Molecules of plastic resist deformation up to certain point and then give up en masse producing cracking sound . Like cracking a stick except some plastic types can bend multiple times before breaking .', "Like you 're an adult : Plastic bags are made up of stretched and hardened polymers to keep the bags inexpensive and strong . This process makes the bags more resistant to movement , and the energy that is expended when you do move the bag is released as sound . Like you 're 10 : Crumpling the bag causes vibrations in its crystalline structure . These vibrations are picked up by our ears as sound . Like you 're 5 : Sound = vibrations . Crumpling a bag = causing vibrations .", "It depends on the material . The crinkly ones , like the one you get at walmart is made from HDPE ( High Density Polyethylene ) material . That material rustles and makes louds noises easily . There are also bags made from LDPE ( Low Density Polyethylene ) and the material is naturally softer and does n't make the loud rustling noises you hear . This type of material is more commonly found in garbage bags and produce rolls . Source : I make bags for a living ."]

['You ca n\'t wrap your head around it because it \'s often misused and misquoted : URL_0 We use it off handedly in conversations to serve a rhetorical purpose , usually to just emphasize how rare an exception is or to show how the specific exception is nt too far of a stretch from the original rule . For example , if Susie only dates rich men , but you say her current boyfriend is n\'t rich , someone else may point out , " no he is n\'t rich , but he \'s a swimsuit model , so if anything that \'s the exception that proves the rule . " literally that is incorrect , but conversationally it is asserting that the general rule is still strong despite your friend \'s argument . In its actual context and full use , as the article explains , it would be something like " No swimming except Sundays , " that exception would prove the general rule that swimming is not allowed Monday through Saturday .', "This is an old expression that comes from the Latin language , and it does n't use the word ' prove ' in the way that we generally do today . When we say ' prove ' we mean ' show that something is true ' . But in this saying , ' prove ' can be replaced by ' test ' ( as in ' proving grounds ' ) . So what it really means is an exception that tests or challenges the validity or truthfulness of the rule . So if the ' rule ' is that all lobsters are brown , a blue lobster would be the exception that proves the rule , not because it proves that all lobsters are brown , but because it challenges the validity of the rule . Here 's a Straight Dope article that explains it more thoroughly : URL_0", 'The word " prove " actually means to put something to the test . In modern parlance we generally assume that whatever is being tested has passed the test but in a more literal sense the phrase " the exception proves the rule " means that the exception * dis*proves the rule or at least that it tests how well the rule holds .']

["Just to clarify things: The Net Working Capital is the funds, the capital that will finance the everyday, the short term, operations of a company like buying raw materials, paying wages erc. So, Net Working Capital doesn't have a negative impact. And you should not see the liabilities as beneficial per se. It's rather the fact that with smaller capital to finance the short term operations the company is able to make this EBIT. You can see it as the efficiency of the company, the smaller the net working capital the more efficient the company is (given the EBIT). I hope you find it helpful, it's my first amswer here. Edit: why do you say the net working capital has a negative impact?"]

["Sales taxes are charged at the point of purchase, while a VAT is assessed during the production process of the item. In the end, the amount paid by the consumer is the same, but with the VAT, the tax was collected from the manufacturer, instead of the consumer. One of the big arguments for VAT is that it prevents lost revenue due to things like smuggling (if sales tax increases past 10% smuggling spikes, so the VAT is a good mechanism if you're looking to implement large taxes on goods). It also keeps the tax burden away from shippers and other tiers of the production process that don't change the intrinsic value of the item."]

["You ca n't prove a negative . For example , you ca n't prove that ghosts do n't exist , because you would need to check every point in space at every point in time and show that there is n't a ghost there , which is not possible . Since you ca n't prove they do n't exist , anyone who says they do needs to prove it , because that would be trivial to do . Simply showing me a ghost would be proof that they exist . However , even if there is no proof that ghosts do n't exist , it still does n't prove that they actually do . You would need to actually show me that ghost . What this means is that in legal situations where something ca n't be proven to not exist , the burden of proof is on the other party . Me not being able to prove I did n't commit a crime does n't prove that I did . Someone needs to provide proof that I actually did for a conviction .", "The stuff about proving a negative is true , but I think the term is used specifically in IP and patent law cases where the owner of patent would normally be required to prove that her patent is the only way to make some product . For example , Anna invents a machine that makes AnnaSnacks and she patents it . A few months later , Bob starts selling AnnaSnacks . As far as Anna knows , her machine is the only way to make AnnaSnacks so she sues Bob for violating her patent . Since it 's basically impossible for Anna to prove that there 's no other way to make AnnaSnacks , the Court will either shift the burden of proof on Bob so that Bob has to prove he can make AnnaSnacks in a different way or it will give Anna legal authority to go inspect Bob 's operation so she can see if he 's using her patent without permission .", 'It \'s any situation where you are required ( usually by a court ) to prove something that it would be impossible or unreasonable to prove . The classic example would be " Prove that the devil does not exist . " You can not prove the non - existence of something . The solution is to shift the burden of proof to the other party : prove that the devil does exist .']

['Many other countries do not use AC . Much of Europe is cool and does not need it . Those parts that could use it use traditional architecture such as high ceilings to make it less needed . Other nations are too poor to use AC .', "I live in Spain , by law new buildings have to have central ac installation , even if you do n't have the AC machine . Old buildings here do n't have them because people could n't afford AC before .", "Central air conditioning is pretty standard outside of the US in large buildings , such as factories , malls and office buildings . It 's also used in some residential buildings , such as passive houses . The main reason you do n't see it that often in residential buildings is that it tends to lead to very dry air in cold winters : When you heat up cold outside air , it 's going to be bone dry when it comes out of the vents . It 's also more difficult to control the temperature in each room , since opening and closing the vents in one room will change the rate of air flowing out of every other vent in the house . All those problems can be fixed by recirculating some of the air , using humidifiers and putting thermostats in the vents in each room . Needless to say though , this makes it quite expensive . Central water heating systems are much easier to regulate , since the waterflow through each radiator can be controlled by a passive thermostat . There 's also no need for a humidifier , since you can just vent some air to get rid of the humidity that builds up . If you can get away with fans in hot summers or if you do n't have a lot of rooms , this is usually the better option for residential buildings ."]

['Ants are eusocial insects of the family Formicidae and, along with the related wasps and bees, belong to the order Hymenoptera. Ants evolved from vespoid wasp ancestors in the Cretaceous period. More than 13,800 of an estimated total of 22,000 species have been classified. They are easily identified by their geniculate (elbowed) antennae and the distinctive node-like structure that forms their slender waists.
Ants form colonies that range in size from a few dozen predatory individuals living in small natural cavities to highly organised colonies that may occupy large territories and consist of millions of individuals. Larger colonies consist of various castes of sterile, wingless females, most of which are workers (ergates), as well as soldiers (dinergates) and other specialised groups. Nearly all ant colonies also have some fertile males called "drones" and one or more fertile females called "queens" (gynes). The colonies are described as superorganisms because the ants appear to operate as a unified entity, collectively working together to support the colony.
Ants have colonised almost every landmass on Earth. The only places lacking indigenous ants are Antarctica and a few remote or inhospitable islands. Ants thrive in moist tropical ecosystems and may exceed the combined biomass of wild birds and mammals. Their success in so many environments has been attributed to their social organisation and their ability to modify habitats, tap resources, and defend themselves. Their long co-evolution with other species has led to mimetic, commensal, parasitic, and mutualistic relationships.
Ant societies have division of labour, communication between individuals, and an ability to solve complex problems. These parallels with human societies have long been an inspiration and subject of study. Many human cultures make use of ants in cuisine, medication, and rites. Some species are valued in their role as biological pest control agents. Their ability to exploit resources may bring ants into conflict with humans, however, as they can damage crops and invade buildings. Some species, such as the red imported fire ant (Solenopsis invicta) of South America, are regarded as invasive species in other parts of the world, establishing themselves in areas where they have been introduced accidentally.']

["Online multiplayer . It 's not worth development resources to put in a feature that will get very little use .", "In addition to the rise of online multiplayer , there have been some other issues : * Game mechanics : Split - screens ca n't fairly go up against each other , which restricts them from free - for - all styled game types , and modern games have tended towards more complex multiplayer than was possible previously . This complexity is actively facilitated by the wall of separation that exists with online multiplayer . * Hardware limitations : The previous set of consoles were n't really up to the task in terms of processing power . Rendering two views at half the resolution is more intensive than one view at full , which meant many games would be pushing the limits . * Screen real estate : The switch from 4:3 to 16:9 has devastating consequences . The old horizontal split that worked on 4:3 is now too thin , and maintaining the 16:9 aspect is often accomplished with black boxing . As well , the limited resolution for a split screen often causes graphics to present badly , which negatively impacts the product .", 'The Internet gives . Back in the day , the only way you could play with a friend was if they were sitting next to you . No mas .']

['An intrusion detection system (IDS; also intrusion prevention system or IPS) is a device or software application that monitors a network or systems for malicious activity or policy violations. Any intrusion activity or violation is typically reported either to an administrator or collected centrally using a security information and event management (SIEM) system. A SIEM system combines outputs from multiple sources and uses alarm filtering techniques to distinguish malicious activity from false alarms.\nIDS types range in scope from single computers to large networks. The most common classifications are network intrusion detection systems (NIDS) and host-based intrusion detection systems (HIDS). A system that monitors important operating system files is an example of an HIDS, while a system that analyzes incoming network traffic is an example of an NIDS. It is also possible to classify IDS by detection approach. The most well-known variants are signature-based detection (recognizing bad patterns, such as malware) and anomaly-based detection (detecting deviations from a model of "good" traffic, which often relies on machine learning). Another common variant is reputation-based detection (recognizing the potential threat according to the reputation scores). Some IDS products have the ability to respond to detected intrusions. Systems with response capabilities are typically referred to as an intrusion prevention system. Intrusion detection systems can also serve specific purposes by augmenting them with custom tools, such as using a honeypot to attract and characterize malicious traffic.']

['There are reasons why some people do not like feminism : Some people do not like feminism because they think that women are already equal or more important in the law . Anti - feminists often say that society is also not equal for men and that women have more rights in child custody and divorce . Some say that feminism wants women to be more important than men . Some argue that women and men have simple biological differences , and thus can not be treated in the same way . Some examples are : the treatment and role of women in the military and pregnancy only happens to women . Some people do not like feminism because it wants to change society and it could make men have less power . Feminism could give women special rights that would then hurt other groups and their rights . An example would be a fear that women would take away jobs normally done by men . Some religious people say that feminism is not what God wanted . For example , in Genesis chapter 2 it says that God made Eve ( the first woman ) as a companion for Adam ( the first man ) and some think this means he made women to serve men . But some feel that God created men and women to be equal ( see Ephesians 5:21 ) . This leads to Christian and Jewish denominations differing on the ordination of women ( whether women can be official leaders in a church . See also Women in Islam . There are also many other types of anti - feminism . Writers such as Camille Paglia , Christina Hoff Sommers , Jean Bethke Elshtain , Elizabeth Fox - Genovese and Daphne Patai oppose some forms of feminism , though they identify as feminists . They argue , for example , that feminism often promotes misandry ( hatred of men ) and the elevation of women \'s interests above men \'s , and criticize radical feminist positions as harmful to both men and women . Daphne Patai and Noretta Koertge argue that the term " anti - feminist " is used to silence academic debate about feminism . Source : URL_0', "Everybody is going so in depth on these replies when it 's pretty simple The more extreme and vocal feminists correlate everything to rape , view facts that do n't agree with their beliefs as misogyny , are often hypocritical ( but who is n't ) , and are more vocal so when the average person thinks of feminism that 's who they picture", 'Most of those who are anti - feminists view the third - wave movement as simply being a load of misandry , especially against the whole " all men are pigs and should die " thing and the turning of blind eyes towards men getting raped or abused .']

['The edge of the blade is atoms , so it would be like trying to split beach balls with beach balls .', "Presumably your knife is made of atoms too , and the edge could n't be any narrower than an atom itself . So it would be like trying to cut a block of stone by hitting it with an equally sized block of stone . Needless to say it would n't be that effective . Another problem is that the atom is surrounded by a field of electrons which are going to interact with the electron field of the atoms in the knife before the nucleus . For another analogy it would be like trying to cut a golf ball in half with another golf ball , except both golf balls are inside their own separate cars . If you hit one car with the other car it is just likely to move the car around before the golf balls interact .", 'The strong interaction that binds the components of an atom together is incredibly strong . At the scale of an atom , it is estimated to be 10 ^ 38 ( one with 38 zeros ) stronger as the gravitational force . Furthermore , an atom is incredibly small , the tip of your knife contains billions of them , so good luck with hitting the middle .']

['It really depends . There are several types of headaches : tension , cluster , migraine , and some others that are much more rare . ELI5 , round one for the major causes : Little pipes full of blood pump that blood to your brain . Sometimes the pipes get too big , which causes little pain wires to get excited . This hurts . ( ELI20 : vasodilation causes stimulation of the nociceptors , which your brain interprets as pain . ) ELI5 , round two : sometimes we tense our muscles too much , which causes the same pain wires to fire . This hurts . ( ELI20 : tension headaches can be caused by muscle tension , often secondary to stress . Eliminate the tension or stress , or both , and the pain should subside . One way to do this is to flex the muscle that is causing the pain- often the trapezoids- shrug your shoulders to your ears until the muscles are very tense , then allow them to fall limp . ) ELI5 , round three : Sometimes our bodies suck . Your head can get ouchy because of this . ( ELI20 : genetics can predispose us to migraines . This is unfortunate , and we should try to avoid any " triggers . " Triggers are usually things like caffeine , coffee , chocolate , etc . ) NB : If you want to know more , I suggest reading [ this section ] ( URL_0 ) of the wikipedia entry for headaches . It has a lot of information , but what you should try to key in on is the type , location , and duration of the pain . This can help you when you talk to your primary care provider about fixing the problem . Hope you feel better ! :)', "The most common type of headache is caused from the muscles in your scalp and neck being too tense . We do n't know what causes Migraines though .", 'Pinch the bridge of your nose . Headache relief from doctor oz']

["The 'appropriate' amount of cash/bonds to hold will be largely a matter of opinion, but here are the general reasons why having at least some is a good idea: Cash is very liquid, and bonds are often mostly liquid. This means you can access them very quickly, without taking on losses. To get the most liquidity out of your bonds, you can do what is called 'laddering'. This means that you take out different bond amounts with different maturity dates, and periodically renew them on a schedule, so that you always have some bonds maturing, which you can access without paying an interest penalty. You can look this term up online for more details. Cash and bonds are low risk. If you have absolutely no low-risk assets, then in the event of, say, a market crash, you may have no savings to fall back on. By owning some bonds, and some equities, you are able to earn a modest return, without being too risky. However, note that some bonds are just as risky as equities - any bond which pays an abnormally high interest rate does so because the entity backing the repayment (government, company, whomever) is thought to not be guaranteed to be able to do so. The 25% figure given by your author is his opinion on the appropriate mix of cash/bonds to equities, but there are many views on the matter. Consider that any 'rule of thumb' in personal finance should be for general consideration only."]

['Stem cells are cells in your body that have n\'t yet turned into something specific . People start as a single , fertilized cell . They then start dividing into lots and lots of cells , eventually become hair , bones , teeth , spleens , all that stuff . Stem cells are the cells that in 1 circumstance could become a toenail , in another circumstance become a brain cell , in another become part of your colon . Another related term is \' undifferentiated \' . They could become a lot of things . It \'s not quite as simple as , say , sticking stem cells into a paraplegic and shzam ! they can walk . But they could be that simple . We need to do more research . They \'re not getting funded because they \'re tied up in the debate about abortion . At the time of birth , the cells are mostly done dividing up into their jobs . You \'ve got a lot of organs that need to get bigger , but you \'re mostly functional when you \'re born . So humans from day 1 do n\'t have many stem cells left , and the ones they do have are a different sort . I say " many " because there are some stem cells in umbilical blood and stuff like that . But there are lots of stem cells present in the fetus . But the main reason people are against it is the idea that , if stem cells are very useful , people might get pregnant and have the embryo or fetus aborted just for parts , basically . That \'s the ELI5 - pretty light on the science and ethical controversy . Edit : Grammaaarrrrgh .', "The reason they are not getting funding is a religious one which is then turned into a political reason . Also this is almost completely a US issue , most other western countries have allowed this research for a long time . The restrictions that exist are more than likely putting the US behind in this field of research . Basically , religious groups say life begins at fertilisation ( when the sperm meets the egg ) . The main source for EMBRYONIC stem cells is fertilised eggs left over from * in vitro * ( test tube ) fertilisation ( IVF ) . Religious groups see these eggs as ' potential humans ' , therefore destroying them is murder of a human being . This is closely related to religious views on abortion . If the religious groups conceded that * in vitro * fertilised eggs were OK to be used for research ( many of them go into the bin if not wanted by the couple who provided the eggs and sperm ) then scientists and pro - abortion advocates could rightly ask ' what is the difference between a in vitro fertilised egg and a fertilised egg in a womb ? ' And really there is NONE apart from location . This would lead to a ' loss of ground ' for religious groups in the abortion arena . So basically , religious groups will probably never support stem - cell research from embryonic sources . They are against * in vitro * fertilisation ( IVF ) too , as this destroys ' potential humans ' too . If they had their way they would ban IVF in the first place so there would be no surplus embryos to use for research . The fact that IVF exists at all is too far for religious groups . ( Note these are not my views , just explaining why the US initially restricted the use of embryonic stem cells )", "Cells are like people , when we grow up we all take different jobs and look different . But just like people , cells all came from the same place , tiny babies that look alike and do n't do anything . Stem cells are just baby cells , they do n't do much except turn into other types of cells ."]

['I think it \'s only a taboo in older generations who grew up with a pretty black and white understanding of mental illness . My dad was born in the 40s and went to Vietnam . He was later diagnosed with PTSD and bipolar disorder , which he thinks is all bullshit . To paraphrase him , you \'re either crazy or you ai n\'t . You \'re either a retard or you ai n\'t . If you read authors like Faulkner and Steinbeck who wrote around that time period before mental illness was really well - explored , you \'ll notice that the mentally ill characters are similarly characterized in pretty vague , stigmatized terms . Like " Bob was slow / dim - witted / etc . " By contrast , a lot of the younger generations ( kids on tumblr , for example ) seem to pride themselves on diagnosis and self - diagnosis of mental illnesses as some kind of proof of individuality and having a complex mind . I knew a guy in high school who tried to convince everyone that he had aspergers because he thought that somehow made him more unique and intelligent than everyone else . You \'ll notice that it only happens with the more romanticized , movie - plot sort of mental illnesses like autism and schizophrenia . Thirteen year olds do n\'t typically go around trying to convince people that they are mentally retarded because that is a disability which is still stigmatized to this day in the way that the whole of mental illness was perceived in my father \'s time .', "For some it 's because it 's assumed that mentally ill people are incapable of functioning in the real world . You do n't see a lot of high functioning mentally ill people saying a lot about it because it would hurt them professionally . You do n't want a depressed manager or account , because you do n't think they can do it . So people hide it if they can . No one wants to have that around their necks on a job hunt , because it 's hard enough if you 're normal . So the ones you hear about are the ones who ca n't function because most of them are open . And it 's a circle .", 'For older generations it \'s because they grew up at a time when nobody talked about it and anyone though to have a mental illness was locked up and never seen again . There is also the " Hollywood factor " . Many films portray those with mental health problems as mad axe murderers .']

["physics . because the snake is held vertically , attacking the holder 's body means moving its mass sideways and counteracting the torque at the pivot . the farther out the snake goes , the more difficult that move becomes . on top of that , the snake moving its center of mass sideways moves its entire body in the opposite direction as the center of gravity tries to reach equilibrium and the 3rd law of motion has its way . you can see when several of the snakes try and get him sideways but they end up flopping about . this is why . this actually does n't work on smaller snakes . their body mass is low enough that they can suspend nearly their entire body weight , or even scale themselves vertically . edit : it may also be that being in that position induces some amount of lethargy . that 's just speculation though . i m an engineer , not a snake person .", "I ca n't speak for what 's going on in the vid , but I was taught ( by multiple naturalists / conservationists ) to always hold a ( wild ) snake firmly right behind its head , to prevent it from curling around and biting you .", "Snakes are n't very bright - they do n't realize that the leg and the thing holding their tail are the same animal ."]

['Science fiction set in a sort of alternate Victorian Britain . Technology is more advanced that it actually was in the 1890s , but in a different direction : there \'s no internal combustion engine , and everything is powered by steam . The science is quite " soft " , and mostly relies on everything being cool enough that the readers wo n\'t notice how infeasible most of the technology is . Arguably based off the works of Jules Verne , but taken in a completely different direction since . Some steampunk settings include fantasy elements as well . Edit : There \'s really no simple way to explain it . It \'s an entire genre and setting . The best way you could learn about it is to read some steampunk things .', "To understand steampunk , you must first understand cyberpunk . Cyberpunk is effectively film noir set in an 80s/90s concept of the high - tech near future in a society dominated by large corporations , with strong brand awareness as a recurring theme amid seamy tales of industrial espionage and corporate politics . Steampunk is a derivative of cyberpunk . Instead of an 80s/90s concept of a high - tech near future , it is set in a Victorian - Britain concept of one . Thus instead of neon , black plastic and Japanese kitsch , the aesthetics are dominated by riveted brass instrumentation everywhere , pneumatic tubes , oak paneling , zeppelins and occasionally fanciful ray - guns . The society depicted is typically more Victorian - dominated by the state and military rather than commercial interests , and the protagonists , while roughly fitting the noir genre , tend to be more accidental adventurers and slightly dashing engineers than the cynical , gritty anti - heroes that dominate cyberpunk . Steampunk as an aesthetic rather than literary genre simply consists of a design aesthetic based on a weird mix of art deco , Boy 's Own Paper and early science fiction .", "Today 's technology , if plastics had never been invented ."]

["Money . More people want to watch that than actual scientific programming . Do n't blame the companies , blame the consumers .", 'These unscripted reality shows are really , really cheap to produce , mostly because there \'s always some idiot willing to do pretty much anything to be on television . It \'s not so much " a million viewers watch Super Science Show , 10 million watch Redneck Rangers , let \'s make more shows like Redneck Rangers . " It \'s " Super Science Show costs us $ 1 million an episode to make , Redneck Rangers costs us $ 50,000 . Even if we \'re losing viewers in droves , we still make more money . "', "Those other shows generate money . It 's actually very similar to how the news has evolved over time . Originally the government gave networks the right to broadcast but required them to provide news as well . Networks lost money on the news consistently , year after year , but it was part of the deal . At some point they realized they could make money on the news by providing content that was n't really newsworthy . At any rate , this is the same as what has happened with those channels . True education and science does n't make as much money ."]

["a function is just a procedure , whereas a class can encapsulate several different internally defined functions ( called methods in the context of a class ) . functions are _ callable _ , which means that it can be invoked to cause the program to compute the procedure defined in the function and return the result . classes are not called the same way functions are , rather they are _ instantiated _ as objects . in instance of a class ( an object ) has properties and methods and the methods are basically callable functions in their own right . another difference that you will often see talked about is that classes can _ inherit _ from other classes . this is a way of defining hierarchical relationships between classes such that a descendant class has all of the properties and methods of the parent class it inherits from . it can then override inherited methods and/or add new ones as needed . this is a pattern that makes it easier to re - use code . there 's alot more to say about the topic and the above is a very crude summary . hopefully its adequate for a start , but if you 're still learning I 'd recommend not worrying too much about classes and just try understand basic procedural programming first .", 'A function does something . A class is a bunch of them .', "Your car is an instance of the Car class , which inherits from the Vehicle class ( among others ) . Your car has lots of methods , such as myCar.unlockDoors ( ) , myCar.getFuelLeve ( ) , and myCar.addToTrunk ( parcel ) . ( Notice that the last takes an argument , the object to be added to the trunk ) . Functions are just sets of instructions with some information to tell the language how they work . Each method of a class is implemented as a function , for example . You could also write a standalone function to do something that does n't require a context , such as a mathematical operation ."]

["it will diffuse into space . Space is a near - perfect vacuum â€” its pressure is nearly zero and it has extremely little matter ( in the empty parts , at any rate ) . On the other hand , your bottle has a relatively high pressure . When you remove the barrier ( by opening the cap ) , the air naturally flows to the region of low pressure . Once there , it creates a localized blob of air , with low pressure â€” but not as low as the surrounding space . This localised blob will spread out due to the pressure difference . Theoretically , it will spread to every corner of the universe , if we neglected gravity and the fact that the universe has other stuff in it . Anyway , it will very very extremely negligibly marginally increase the pressure of the local zone . That 's about it â€” the air just spreads out . Sort of like what happens when you put a drop of red food coloring in a tank of water â€” it first creates a localized red blob , which spreads out till the change in color is negligible . Note that this process , in space , will be much faster than the red food coloring one . The two are similar phenomena but the mechanics are different .", "When something like that happens , the ejection of the air from whatever container its in into space is going to cause the air particles to travel with a certain velocity . In space , outside of gravity , you 're going to keep going in whatever direction you are travelling in , at the speed you are travelling in . So eventually those air particles would disperse to the point where they might as well not be there . This holds true for pretty much any material you let loose in space - its going to travel in whatever direction its initial velocity takes it in , and keeps going until its affected by gravity or physical contact with another object in space . If that material ca n't retain a solid physical shape , its going to disperse and eventually be so dispersed that only trace elements ( if anything at all ) could be detected .", "It disperses or spreads out . It 's like the smoke from your cars tailpipe , it comes out in a group but quickly thins out ."]

["Fish have an extraordinarily sensitive vibration detection system called lateral lines . Tapping on the bowl is kind of like walking up to a person and clanging cymbals beside their ears . It 's very rude .", "It 's to protect the fish , not the glass .", "Mostly it 's for the reasons listed above , but * very occasionally * it 's also to protect the integrity of the tank . Source : am child of parents whose giant Oscars died in tank - tapping accident"]

['Fans are attracted to it because of the drama . One of the first things a fan has to do is decide what driver to follow . NASCAR is not like other sports where its one on one ( one person vs one person , or one team vs another team ) , its 43 individual drivers all out to win , so fans have their driver to root for , and it becomes 1 vs 42 . Once you have a specific driver to root for , it becomes much more entertaining . Everything your driver does becomes more important ... you hope he qualifies well so he can start towards the front , you hope his crew has built a fast car , you hope the crew chief makes the right decisions so your driver can work up to the front . And of course , there is drama to follow , while everyone has their favorite driver , they also have a few drivers they absolutely HATE , so they root against them , and it makes it more entertaining to watch . Think of Lebron James and the Miami Heat ... some fans rooted for them , but much of the country HATED them , and watched the NBA playoffs hoping other teams would beat them just because they hate Lebron / Heat . That same attitude is what drives fans to NASCAR ... for instance , Kyle Busch is much like Lebron James ... one of the most talented drivers out there , struggles to win a championship , and most of the fans despise him . Jimmie Johnson is alot like the the NE Patriots ... multiple championship winner , consistently makes the " Playoffs " ( NASCAR Chase ) , and many fans root against him because they are just tired of watching him win all the time . There all kinds of analogies you can make between drivers and other sports , so hope that gives you an answer as to why fans enjoy it so much ... its not so much about the racing , as it is about the drama that comes along with it .', 'As a historian I find interesting NASCAR stories all the time , sadly it seems we live in an era where the races are tightly regulated and controlled , to the point where one has to respect finer nuances to really " be a fan " . For instance : check out the biography of [ Smokey Yunick ] ( URL_0 ) . When NASCAR \'s rules allowed for a much larger " gray area " , he would constantly pull antics such as building a roughly 9/10 scale car - totally " stock " by definition yet lighter and more aerodynamic . because of this NASCAR now keeps templates of the stock car parts to measure against the drivers \' vehicles . Another trick he pulled , when limited by a standard - size fuel tank , was to make the fuel line itself 11 feet long - which gave him an extra * five * gallons of fuel . After suspicious race officials removed his fuel tank ... he hopped in the car and drove it back to the pit stop . Of course , pit crews and drivers ca n\'t get away with those sort of stunts these days , but I still think the behind - the - scenes characters and drama still play a major role in the sport , almost as much as the racing itself . In many ways I actually think it \'s fairly similar to baseball , a game I find almost boring to watch yet I am captivated by the personalities that dominate the game .', "I always thought it would be like when I watch poker on T.V. To non fans it 's just a bunch of guys sitting around a table throwing plastic chips around , but I know enough about it to understand what 's going on so it 's entertaining to me . I 'm sure NASCAR must be the same way , to us non fans , it 's just a bunch of guys turning left . But it you know enough about it to understand why the drivers are doing what they 're doing , it could be fun ."]

['40 things amongst each 8 people means each person would get 5 . 40 things divided amongst .5 people means that .5 of a person gets 40 , which means each * whole person * gets 80 .', "Division is an operation that determines how many times one number goes into another number . 40/8 = 5 because you can fit 8 into 40 five times . It just so happens that if you are thinking about dividing things into groups , division lines up very neatly with that and can be used to determine how much each group gets . That 's not what the mathematical operation means , though . A fraction represents a numerical value . When you divide by a fraction , you are determining how many times the numerical value it represents goes into the number you are dividing . Since 1/2 goes into 40 eighty times , you end up with 40/(1/2 ) = 80 . If you really want to think of it conceptually as splitting up items among groups , you could try thinking of it like this : You have 40 apples for 1/2 of a group . You can divide to figure out how many apples you need for one whole group .", 'It can help to think of it in terms of a sentence . 40/8 : I have 40 things , divided into 8 groups . Each group gets 5 . 40/0.5 : I have 40 things , divided into half a group . Each ( whole ) group gets 80 .']

['There already a lot of identifying features in the eyes . Eye position , eye color , length of lashes , etc that could make it easier for a stranger to find them . But , people who already know the person could identify them based on other parts . TL : DR : enough censorship against strangers , just enough for family & friends to recognize', "FWIW , a lot of things censoring identities censor by shrouding them in shadows , blurring or pixelating the face ... Things of that nature . Sometimes multiple techniques are used , but that 's rare . As a side note , one time i saw the shadow technique used in an incredibly half assed manner and it was very very easy to tell what they looked like . I hope nothing bad happened to that guy ; he was a mob informant .", "This is most common in still photos , I think because people focus on the eyes . You are right that it is not the best identity hiding method , but just provides some privacy . TransGirlInCharge listed some methods often used in video . Like her I 've seen videos where you could tell a lot about someone 's features . About 20 years ago there was a televised rape trial involving a member of the Kennedy family . There were two dots used to cover the face of the victim testifying . It was obvious the court used a small dot that barely covered her face . The news decided that was not sufficient and put on a larger circle of a different color that would cover the face and the small dot . As the victim shifted slightly in her seat the large TV dot stayed on her , but the Court dot stayed in the old position for a second and would have completely exposed her face ."]

["Let 's build a cube . A meter tall ( or 100 centimeters , 1,000 .. * millimeters * ) wide and deep . Let 's now fill it with water : Exactly 1,000 liters of water will be needed . For a weight of 1,000 kilos , or a ton . This water will boil at 100 degrees C and freeze at 0C. * oh my god metric 's haaaard , man ! *", 'Because most of us are around 5 feet 7 inches and weigh around 200lbs and drive at an average speed of 50 miles per hour and have temperatures of 98.6 degrees Fahrenheit . The US customary system developed from English units which were in use in the British Empire before American independence . Consequently most US units are virtually identical to the British imperial units . However , the British system was overhauled in 1824 . Advocates of the customary system saw the French Revolutionary , or metric , system as atheistic .', 'The Americans were n\'t invited ( by the French ) to the summit where the rest of The World / Europe made standardized units . I believe the podcast " how stuff works " had an episode about this a few years ago .']

['It \'s all to do with how the game interacts with the operating system . This is different between different operating systems . For example : * * System calls * * System calls are a way for a program ( in this case , the game ) to communicate with the operating system . For example , if the game needs to open a file , it sends a system call to the operating system saying " get me this file " . Exactly how system calls are done varies from one operating system to the next . Each OS will generally have a similar set of system calls to other operating systems , but the specifics are different ( different method of making system calls , different names , different parameters ( parameters are how you pass information to a system call , so for example , the name of the file you want to open would be a parameter ) , etc . ) . * * File and directory structure * * Windows and Linux have different standards for how files are organised on your hard disk . When you install a program on Windows , it usually creates a folder for that program within C:\\Program Files\\ , and the files that program needs are placed in that folder . On Linux , the program itself is usually stored in a directory ( folder ) called /usr / bin , while other files needed by the program are stored in /usr / lib and /usr / share ( among other places ) . Similarly , Windows and Linux have different places that they store your settings and personal files . When porting a program between operating systems , you have to adapt it to understand and use these different ways of organizing files . * * Accessing hardware * * Windows and Linux have different ways of letting programs communicate with hardware . Of particular importance to games is graphics . Most Windows games use something called DirectX to take care of their graphics . DirectX is needed because there are a huge number of different graphics cards out there , and they all have different ways of doing things . When PC gaming first took off , game developers had to specifically design their game to support each graphics card it might be played on . This was fine in the early days when there were only a few models of graphics cards around , but nowadays there are such a huge number of cards available that it would be impossible for a game developer to design for them all individually . So Microsoft created DirectX as a standard way to talk to graphics cards . Now game developers only had to support DirectX , and it was up to each graphics card manufacturer to create drivers , which are programs that let their graphics card " talk DirectX \'s language " . But Linux does n\'t support DirectX. Instead , it has its own similar thing called OpenGL . OpenGL basically does the same stuff as DirectX , but it works differently . Imagine DirectX is like speaking in English and OpenGL is like speaking in French . Games that know how to work with DirectX do n\'t understand OpenGL and vice versa . So the game developers will have to modify their game to work with OpenGL , which is quite a big job because quite often the game \'s entire graphics system will be designed around DirectX. Nowadays OpenGL can run on Windows as well as Linux , so if you are writing a game that you plan to release on both platforms , it makes sense to design it to use OpenGL to begin with . But a lot of games are still build using DirectX , especially if the developer did n\'t originally plan on porting it . There are similar things for other types of hardware , such as sound cards ( WaveOut or DirectSound on Windows , ALSA or Pulse on Linux ) . These will also have to be adapted for . * * Libraries * * When you write a piece of software , you typically do n\'t create the whole thing yourself from scratch . Instead you use libraries , which are pieces of code for doing common tasks that have already been written . For example , there might be a library for playing music files . If your game needs to play back music files ( e.g. for theme music or sound effects ) , why bother writing your own code to do this when you can just use the library ? Think of it like building a house : you \'re not going to cut down a tree and make it into lumber yourself when you can just buy some ready cut wood from a builders yard . This is all great , until you decide you want to convert your game to run on Linux . Windows and Linux both come with their own set of libraries , and they are both different . This is like if you designed your house around metric fittings , only to find the shop only sells imperial . Developers will have to rewrite their game to support the different libraries . There are some libraries that are available on both Windows and Linux , and it helps if developers designed their game around these libraries where possible . But if they were n\'t planning to port their game to Linux when they first wrote it , they might have chosen to use different libraries which only work on Windows . Even where the same library is available on both platforms , sometimes there will be slight difference between the two which you \'ll have to work around . There are a lot of other differences between the two OSes , but this is already pretty long and you could write whole books on the subject ( in fact people already have ) . That said , these are some of the main ones . Hopefully this will give you a good idea of how much work is involved in porting a game , especially if that game was never design to be ported in the first place .', "There are two different ways of telling computers to draw 3D things . The one that most games use is called DirectX , and you ca n't use it on anything but Windows . The other one is called OpenGL , and you can use it on Windows , Mac , AND Linux ! Unfortunately , because most games use DirectX to draw things , in order to run games on Mac and Linux , you have to translate all the DirectX into OpenGL , which is actually really hard .", "It 's a common analogy to say that computer programs are like recipes . And it 's not far off . You have a list of procedures to complete and in the end you have a finished product . Its is however , quite a simplification . In real life , it 's a lot more like a science lab than a kitchen , where you have dozens of complex machines which you must set up and use * just * * right * to get the correct result . This is especially true if you are doing high speed , or low level stuff , which is common in games . If you apply this to the lab analogy , then sure , you need to carry out the same basic procedures . HOWEVER , all the lab equipment is subtly different . This means you need to spend a lot of time reading manuals to convert your procedures from Machine A ( Windows ) to Machine B ( Linux ) . And if you rely on a particular quirk of machine A than does n't exist in machine B , you are going to change that section completely , which often means you end up with slower code ( unacceptable in games ) . Or , you 're just shit out of luck ."]

['Hello . So chemically speaking , the term steroid I dictated a specific structure of a compound / chemical . All steroids are derived from cholesterol so they all have the same basic structure . What makes them different are what is / are attached to the structure . So steroids are differentiated into subclasses ; they do things from stuff like anti - inflammatory , growth , help with breathing , hormone regulation . The mechanism for steroids are all pretty much the same believe it or not when you boil it down in that they act primarily as hormones , telling your body to produce something or to not produce something .', "There are a lot of different types of steroids , all variations on a basic theme ( which has as its core 3 six - membered carbon rings and a five - membered carbon ring attached to each other in a specific orientation . The variations are additional carbon / oxygen atoms attached to the core ) . So they can work in different ways depending on their structure . However , most of those ways have to do with interfering with proliferation of your immune cells . ( B cells and T cells , macrophages , etc . ) This obviously reduces inflammation going on in your body , which can be life - saving ... but on the flip side , the immune suppression can make you vulnerable to infection and cancer , which is why it 's best not to administer them for prolonged periods if at all possible .", 'Steroids are an entire class of chemicals that may be naturally occurring or artificial . Naturally occuring steroids are the chemicals used inside our bodies to regulate biological processes . Artificial steroids are synthetic chemicals that act like the natural steroids so you \'re basically just sending a whole bunch of extra " signals " to do whatever it is that steroid controls .']
